awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Combining Information Theoretic Security and Stochastic Control to Study Advanced Persistent Threats
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite tremendous advances in cryptography and communication security, information attacks -- both passive such as eavesdropping, and active such as unauthorized data injection --, can severely impair the functioning of modern infrastructural systems that combine cyber communication systems and networked physical components. The ability of adversaries to monitor transmitted data or introduce false information for sustained periods of time whilst staying undetected can result in leakage of sensitive information or cause critical damages to underlying systems with consequences ranging from airline collisions, power blackouts to malfunctioning nuclear reactors. In this research, rigorous frameworks are developed to study vulnerabilities of cyber physical systems to such persistent security threats with the goal of designing novel and resilient system controllers. The systematic approach to study adversarial behavior will not only enable effective cyber policing, but also lay a platform for developing technologies to prevent the next generation of cyber terrorism that aims to cripple basic infrastructural systems in energy, healthcare, transportation etc.  The education and outreach components will facilitate an enhanced awareness in society of potential vulnerabilities of the burgeoning Internet of Things and the path towards cyber physical security.
 
This research will study two key challenges in securing cyber physical systems: preventing retrieval of physical system information through continually monitored cyber flows, and limiting disruption to system operations through continually hacked cyber flows. Incorporating the strengths of information theoretic security and statistical inference methodologies into a dynamic programming framework which models cyber physical system evolution as a function of external information and internal control, this research will study quantitatively the trade-offs between information security and the system operational performance, and through the process, develop attack detection and mitigation methodologies.

por.por_cntn:
The major outcomes of the project are several peer reviewed conference and journal publications, and chapters in doctoral theses of four graduate students. The research conducted through this project has also facilitated professional development for the graduate students and career advancement and enhanced visibility for the PI and students in the scientific community. We summarize some of the key research outcomes that have been published for the scientific community below:
1. In a series of papers published in the IEEE Asia-Pacific Signal and Information Processing Conference, Allerton Annual Conference on Communication, Control and Computing, and the IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing, our research outcomes included: i) A generalized version of the classical Lloyd Max iterative algorithm was developed to obtain the optimal biased quantizers that achieve perfect privacy within quantization restraints. ii) For a given privacy requirement determined by a differential privacy parameter, an iterative algorithm was proposed to characterize the optimal quantizer that minimizes a general distortion function. and iii) A real time algorithm was proposed that did not require prior knowledge of the private information and yet achieves (optimal) logarithmic regret in the long term. These results formed the basis of two chapters in the doctoral thesis of Dr. Ruochi Zhang.
2. In a series of papers published in the IEEE Control and Decisions Conference, IEEE Transactions on Control of Network Systems, IEEE American Control Conference, and IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security, our major research outcomes included: i)A formal characterization of the best adversary strategy to attack standard dynamic control systems ii) A method to optimally detect such attacks and iii) A demonstration that these strategies were in fact a "game theoretic" equilibrium. In other words, the detection method ensured that no other attack had greater impact on performance than the one designed for. These results formed the basis for two chapters in the doctoral thesis of Dr. Ruochi Zhang.
3. In a series of papers published in the IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security, IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy (the top security conference), and the IEEE Conference on Acoustics Speech and Signal Processing (flagship Signal Processing conference), our major research outcomes included: i) Algorithms for achieving privacy of "learnable" attributes from real-time sensory data, ii) demonstration of the efficacy of the algorithms on real data sets in health sensors and IoT applications, iii) a novel modification of an online gradient descent algorithm to guarantee provable privacy of the updates to the learned models. These results will contribute to two chapters in the doctoral thesis of Ce Feng.
4. In a paper published in the Proceedings of the IEEE Conference on Information Systems and Sciences, and another journal manuscript in review, our major research outcome included i) An economic analysis of privacy in the context of competing retailers ii) a demonstration that competition can incentivize privacy preservation under circumstances where users can switch loyalties in response to privacy violations such as through the use of coupons for sensitive purchases. These results contributed to a chapted in the doctoral thesis of Dr. Omid Javidbakht
5. In a series of papers including a journal paper in IEEE Transactions of Smart Grid, a game theoretic view of privacy was formally studied where different users with different privacy preferences shared resources. Our major research outcomes included i) identifying conditions in an abstract framework under which users were incentivized to preserve the privacy of the collective, and ii) a study of a practical scenario where users shared an energy storage device where an incentive scheme was devised that ensure that users acted honestly and according to their own privacy preferences. This formed part of the PhD thesis of Dr. Jiyun Yao.
Beyond the specific research outcomes of this project, the work enabled the professional training and funded part of the doctoral research for five students, three of whom have successfully defended their thesis, and the remaining two are close to completion. They were given opportunities to present their research in highly reputed conferences and interact with their scientific peer community. Some of the research directions have also contributed to novel ideas for newer research projects which are currently being pursued by the PI.
